Introduction

This operational policy has been developed in accordance with Cervical Screening Programme and Colposcopy Management Guide, Public Health England 2020: its aim is to ensure women referred for colposcopy experience the following across MSE:
Remove/limit delays to provide an efficient patient pathway
Standardise and improve patient care
Incorporate new research and provide evidence based care
Implement recommendations following clinical audits
Offer excellence as service providers
Involve members of the Multi-Disciplinary Team (MDT).
Provide robust failsafe systems for appropriate follow up
Implement and act upon failsafe breaches from the laboratory.
Improve access to colposcopy services by offering next available appointment across MSE Hospitals
Scope
This operational policy is a means of providing evidence based care and relates to:
Staffing
Service infrastructure
Clinic environment
Referral indications
Clinical practice
It is intended to be a form of guidance and not intended as rules for  practice.

Colposcopy clinics are specialised clinics for the assessment of women who have been referred due to abnormal cervical cell samples, as well as vault samples, atypical cervical appearances and symptoms concerning the cervix. Pre-malignant or malignant disease of the vagina and vulva may also be seen additionally in a clinic, when appropriate. However these patients may not be managed in the colposcopy pathway.
The colposcopy service will have an administrative infrastructure to support and monitor colposcopy referral attendance and follow up as required. Currently two systems are used to facilitate this.
Infoflex database management - to accommodate tracking patient care through their colposcopy journey.
Cyres - concurrently used as a reporting tool for online submission of screening data required by PHE.

It is recognised that the colposcopy service requires adequate dedicated clerical and secretarial support to ensure timely communication with patients and their GPs, acting in line with the Faster Diagnostic Standards 2020. In addition, administrative support is needed to ensure:
Efficient data collection
Effective communication with other agencies
Effective and timely failsafe activities.

Women undergoing colposcopy should have access to a level one registered nurse trained in colposcopy to support them and to act as their advocate during the procedure, whilst a second support nurse also trained in colposcopy is required to assist in making the necessary preparations for cervical sampling, biopsies and treatment, and to support the colposcopist directly during the examination. All colposcopists working in a clinic must receive the same level of nursing staff support. All clinic staff must be familiar with the treatment method(s) used.

Having a dedicated, specialist team in the colposcopy unit provides continuity of care and allows individuals to develop confidence in individual members of staff. This in turn helps reduce anxiety and improves both attendance and satisfaction with the service. The extended role of the nurse colposcopist may be of particular benefit here. Staffing for the service should ensure that there is appropriately trained cover available for planned absences and there is no over-reliance of the service on single individuals.(National Guidelines NSHCSP Feb 2020 1.8)

Further specific protocols and fail-safe, Standard Operation Procedures have been developed and are likewise as important. These are not discussed in this document specifically, however, a full list can be found in appendix

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
The local document control group is responsible for ensuring guidelines are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The Clinical Lead is responsible for Policy adherence.

The Heads of Midwifery, gynaecology matrons and Managers on each site (women's clinic and colposcopy) are responsible for ensuring staff working within colposcopy is aware of the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) and implementation.

The Lead Colposcopist will take overall accountability and responsibility for the quality of the colposcopy service provided by the site. They will ensure that evidence based local guidelines and procedures are in place for the whole site and that these comply with recommended national guidelines, these guidelines and procedures will be regularly reviewed so that the needs of the commissioners and the users of the services are met.

They will ensure that the defined quality assurance standards and indicators are being met. Guarantee that there is a suitable system in place in place to collect the agreed national minimum dataset and produce accurate and validated data for the required mandatory national data returns (including the KC65 returns) and that supports local audit as well as ensuring an annual audit of the service takes place in order to compare practice with the local guidelines and national targets.

They will work with those within the site responsible for providing the facilities for the service to ensure that the service is adequately equipped and staffed by appropriately trained individuals (medical and non-medical) so the service needs can be met in a timely and user-sensitive way.

They will co-ordinate training and work with the British Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (BSCCP) Certification and Training Committee as appropriate, ensuring that they support all staff working in
the colposcopy service, that they are appropriately qualified and undertake required mandatory training.

They will inform divisional management about the need to ensure procedures are in place to enable care and rapid communication with patients, other hospital departments, primary care agencies and cytopathology and histopathology services.

They will convene and chair quarterly colposcopy team operational meetings as well as work with cervical screening provider leads (CSPLs) to convene regular multidisciplinary meetings, including cytology and histology services for case discussion and protocol review.
As the lead for the service they will need to regularly participate in the organization's cervical screening business meetings, organized and chaired by the CSPL.
They will need to regularly communicate with users, providers and purchasers of care to ensure that the service and its development are appropriate and meet the needs of the local population
The Lead colposcopy nurse will support the lead colposcopist in the development and review of evidence based local guidelines, procedures and patient information documents.
They will support the lead colposcopist in the acquisition and validation of data to support the production of quarterly and annual performance information, including the mandatory KC65 return
They will support, and represent the views of, colposcopy nurses and other support staff within the department.
They will ensure appropriate and safe staffing levels, co-ordinate and support the training of nursing and administration staff within the colposcopy service.

They will ensure mandatory training requirements are achieved. They will ensure that within their respective roles, nursing and administration staffs meet a level of competence within the colposcopy service.

They will ensure standards are maintained within the clinical environment, supporting the failsafe processes. They will ensure the provision of an appropriate clinical environment for the day to day delivery of colposcopy that meets standards.
Individual Colposcopists will be responsible for maintaining appropriate updated knowledge and skills in order to practice as an accredited
colposcopist. Accreditation will be through the British Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology ( BSCCP) every 3 years.

They will be responsible for demonstrating an appropriate knowledge of administration procedures for their colposcopy patients and work within these local failsafe systems. They will be responsible for appropriate patient care and management.
They will be responsible for the accuracy of both written and electronic data written/ completed at the time of initial consultation.
They will be responsible for attending regular meetings upon invitation. They must attend at least 50% of colposcopy MDT meetings.
The Lead histopathologist will be responsible for maintaining suitable continuing professional development (CPD) which meets programme standards for reporting cervical histology.

They will participate in histopathology EQA schemes and work with the CSPL and Lead Biomedical Scientist to make sure the laboratory follows all national guidance related to cervical screening histology.
They will advise on the implementation of new guidance or monitoring of new standards as published by the CSP or RCPath when appropriate.
They will ensure standards in cervical histology reporting meets standards at an MDT meeting.
They will be responsible for making sure the necessary pathology input is made for cases in the national audit of invasive cervical cancer.

They will ensure cervical screening services meetings (local and regional), where trust business issues or performances are monitored and discussed will be represented and contributed as necessary to, by the department. They will supply any specific quality reports as requested.
They will advise and participate in audits for the local programme relevant to their role. They will contribute to any annual reports relating to the local service.
They will have the responsibility of signing off the cervical histology data returns.
They will be the primary medical contact within the department for cervical screening histology matters.
They will ensure that an appropriately experienced histopathologist undertakes a review of histological biopsies that are included in MDT meetings and invasive cancer audit.
The lead for Cytopathology will be responsible for maintaining suitable continuing professional development (CPD) which meets program standards for reporting cervical cytology.

They will be a consultant cellular pathologist registered on the GMC specialist register or a consultant biomedical scientist in cervical cytology registered with the Health and Care Professions Council.

They should participate in the cervical cytology EQA schemes and work with the CSPL and Lead Biomedical Scientist to ensure the laboratory follows all national guidance related to cervical screening protocols and quality standards.
They will advise on the implementation of new guidance or monitoring of new standards as published by the CSP.
They will ensure standards in cervical cytology reporting meets standards at an MDT meeting.
They will be responsible for making sure the necessary slide review is undertaken for cases in the national audit of invasive cervical cancer.
They will prepare reports and attend Cervical Screening Program Board meetings and ensure that there is laboratory representation in their absence.
They will prepare a report and/or attend colposcopy business meetings as required.
They will advise and participate in audits for the local program relevant to their role. They will contribute to any annual reports relating to the local service.
They will ensure that data is collected and returned to SQAS or other agencies as required.
They will be the primary contact within the department for cervical screening cytology matters.
They will ensure that an appropriately experienced cytologist undertakes a review of cases for MDT meetings and invasive cancer audit.

Attend cervical screening multidisciplinary meetings or ensure that 100% of multidisciplinary team (MDT) meetings are attended by a suitably qualified person such as another medical consultant or consultant biomedical scientist.

The Cervical Screening Provider Lead will ensure that operational policies and quality management systems are implemented across the programme (in conjunction with clinical and operational leads). They will oversee effective failsafe systems for all women referred to colposcopy, in line with the requirements set out in NHSCSP guidance.

The Colposcopy Co-ordinators will be responsible for acting upon the laboratories daily Direct Referrals, issuing appropriate appointments, rescheduling appointments/clinics on the instruction of the relevant Colposcopist, preparing patient notes prior to clinic appointments if required, typing all correspondence to referring doctors and patients and ensuring patient episodes and notes are scanned onto an electronic patient documentation or added to patient notes in a timely manner.

The Session Nurse/s (RN / HCA) should ensure he/she is familiar with appropriate Health and Safety regulations and clinic protocols. They will be responsible for ensuring appropriate facilities and equipment are available and ready for use in each clinic, assisting the Colposcopist and supporting the patient throughout the examination, sending equipment to CSSD when clinic is completed and cleaning and tidying clinic areas. They will also be responsible for correctly preparing and labelling cervical screening samples and histology specimens ready for transportation to the laboratory. Other duties include providing advocacy, counselling and advice to patients after colposcopy/treatment and maintaining adequate stock levels and equipment.

All Clinic support staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this Standard Operating Procedure in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to work within colposcopy sessions. They should be working towards or be signed off on their competencies.
Referral indication

MSE foundation Trust has 3 colposcopy sites; Basildon, Broomfield and Southend hospitals each have a colposcopy department. Cross cover will be afforded to each site within the trust as required. In the event of cross covering staff will need to familiarise themselves with site specific equipment and procedures.
All Three sites receive referrals via the following routes:
Direct referrals – from the cytology laboratory (see primary HPV algorithm below)
Genito-Urinary Medicine Clinics,
Family Planning Clinics,
Hospital consultants,
Gynaecology out patients,
Gynae emergency units
General Practitioners - can also refer by letter, email, ICE, and Choose and Book (Referral Advise System).

To assist appropriate and timely appointments these referrals are channelled through one of the site specific nurse colposcopists. They will triage these to ensure appropriate utilisation of available clinic appointments in conjunction with the colposcopy facilitators.

Clinic schedules

In order to provide an efficient service, systems and personnel should be in place to ensure adequate colposcopy appointments are available at all times. In order to minimise patient risk and ensure continuity of patient care, unscheduled colposcopy sessions should be avoided, unless it would seriously hamper urgent patient diagnosis.

The Trust aims to operate all site sessions directed towards “see and treat” clinics; appropriate treatment can be performed at the same appointment. Some clinics will include a patient case mix (ie. new referrals and follow up patients some of whom may be treated). There may be situations where additional patients can be added to a fully booked clinic if agreed by the sessional colposcopist.

Due to the nature of colposcopy, “choose and book” will not be used. Instead patients are booked through “partial booking” system, and an appropriately worded letter will be sent to the patient along with a suitable patient information leaflet (see OG 304) . The GP will also be informed of the st offered appointment.

Unless specifically requested in any referral, all patients will be deemed a “generic referral” and will be allocated an appropriate appointment (observing referral intervals and availability of clinic appointments). By using a generic referral better optimisation of resources can be achieved and patients waiting times for appointments are observed appropriately.
The colposcopy service has dedicated Administration Staff. Only these staff can book colposcopy appointments, change clinic schedules and book follow up appointments.

All colposcopists have agreed numbers for clinic caseload (minimum 6 new direct). Additional patient requiring treatment/opinion can be allocated at short notice above the template, to ensure compliance to standards set

– (KPI - 90% of patients should have definitive treatment for High Grade CIN within 4 weeks of receiving colposcopist the histology of the diagnostic biopsy, if this is not possible any other colposcopist can perform the treatment).

Additionally, there may be other trained or trainee colposcopists who are members of the service team on a transient basis and subject to terms of employment. Copies of a valid accreditation certificate will be required and kept for the duration of the placement by the colposcopy office.
If a supervised trainee is present a reduced case mix is suggested:
See appendix 3d for details of Site specific clinics times/days
Cancellation of clinics

7.9.1  Cancellation of clinics due to scheduled leave or other sanctioned activity is built into the system. On occasion, a short notice cancellation/deferment is needed and the priority is to re-allocate the clinic to an available nurse colposcopist rather than cancel the clinic in the first instance.
Clinic facilities
Each clinic's facilities must include:
A private area with changing facilities
Toilet facilities
A permanently sited specific room for colposcopy
Refreshment facilities
Separate waiting and recovery areas
Access for individuals with disabilities
Equipment in the colposcopy clinic must include:
A permanent couch and colposcope
Suitable sterile instruments, set up separately for each individual, compliant with national health and safety recommendations
Adequate and immediately accessible resuscitation equipment, and staff involved in the clinical care of patients who are familiar and trained in its use
Suitable IT equipment

Software for the collection of data for submission of the mandatory quarterly and annual KC65 return, clinic and individual screening quality assurance service data returns and audits, BSCCP accreditation requirements and to support local audit programs.
Daily back up of all data, and disaster recovery arrangements must be in place
Where possible, television monitoring facilities for patients who wish to watch the procedure (image capture is advantageous)
Visitors in clinic
7.11.1 Individuals undergoing a colposcopy+/- treatment should be able to have a friend or relative present if they wish.
7.11.2 A patient's consent should be sought prior to colposcopy if anyone not essential for its performance is to be present (for example trainees or undergraduates).
7.11.3 Professional visitors wishing to attend a colposcopy session should seek permission via the colposcopy lead or co-ordinators before attending.
Communication

There are several agencies involved in the efficient running of the cervical cytology screening programme. Colposcopy represents a small but essential part of this programme. It is important to note that women who have had abnormal cervical samples are removed from recall and placed on the suspended register by the agency responsible for generating the call and recall programme. It is, therefore, essential that communication is maintained regarding colposcopy visits and the re-establishment of the patients' cytology pathway. This is by way of an electronic discharge list sent monthly to the agency responsible.
Patient communication
8.2.1 Verbal

Patients should be informed of what has occurred at the visit, what and why (if any) treatment was required and what should happen next. This information should be given at the end of the colposcopic assessment. This will reiterate advice given, possible side effects, what to do in the event of a complication and a contact number for advice.
They will be advised that a written resume will be sent to them (the patient, the referrer and national recall agency advised of the planned recall interval.)
8.2.2 Written

This resume should detail colposcopy history, current status and future management plans and should be sent to the woman within four weeks of her visit to the colposcopy clinic (90%). This resume should also contain a phone number for further advice.
GP communication
8.3.1  Written
GPs will receive the same copy as the patient receives.
Counselling and consent

Patients will have been given printed information in their original invitation to the clinic and may have been counselled by their general practitioner, practice nurse or colposcopy nurse specialist, prior to their colposcopy visit by telephone.

On arrival the patient should be given further verbal information at the time her history is taken and given the opportunity to discuss her feelings and anxieties. It is important that this phase of counselling is very positive and supportive. She should be advised of what may be found and what/if any treatment may be necessary.
Written consent for treatment under general analgesia is required. Verbal consent should be documented on the Colposcopy Clinic opinion sheet.
Documentation
Patient notes (electronic/paper) are available for the appointment. The direct referring cervical sample result will be made available.

All information and colposcopic opinion should be input directly on to the Infoflex database system at the time of the visit by the colposcopist. The colposcopy proforma with its diagrams will form part of the notes (paper /electronic).

If a tampon is required after a punch biopsy, it should be recorded on the clinical documentation and a hand-out should be given to the patient outlining aftercare and a time for removal of the tampon clearly stated.

Swabs and needles (Cotton wool balls and gauze swabs and packs) should be counted at the beginning and end of the procedure by the session nurse and colposcopist and recorded on the site specific clinical documentation. It is the responsibility of the colposcopist to dispose of sharps.

In the event of a patient needing packing for a primary haemorrhage following treatment, this should be recorded on the clinical documentation, and site specific LocSSIP for Invasive Procedures should be adhered to.
In the event of a patient being taken ill during or after a procedure site specific procedures should be followed.
Telephone consultations should be recorded on the infoflex data base.
It is the responsibility of the colposcopist seeing the woman to ensure that she is:
Aware of the reason for the visit
Assessed for her understanding of the presenting abnormality
Has questions answered to her satisfaction, to allay fears and anxieties.
Is provided with an explanation re the ‘select /see and treat' options (where appropriate)
Provides and informed consent which should be documented
Provides verbal consent for digital image capture
Given appropriate discharge/post treatment advice leaflets /hand-outs which should be documented
Provided an opportunity to discuss any residual concerns
Colposcopy result letters should not be documented outside of the dedicated service.

Operation notes of patients, who have had a general anaesthetic, should be filed in the main notes / uploaded to Electronic Documentation systems ASAP after the procedure in order for the colposcopy coordinators to accurately complete the episode and inform all relevant parties in a timely manner.

data.text: Treatment for CIN
Available options include:
Local Ablative Treatments (Cold Coagulation, Diathermy)
Excisional biopsy - LLETZ (large Loop Excision of Transformation Zone) NETZ (Needle Excision of the Transformation Zone) CKCB – (Cold Knife Cone Biopsy)
Hysterectomy
All women MUST undergo Urinary HCG pregnancy testing
prior to LLETZ/Ablation. This result should be recorded in the notes.
12.4.1 Local ablative treatments

These should only be used for low grade lesions after suitable colposcopic  and histological assessment. The following conditions should apply when  considering local ablative treatments (National Guidelines NHSCSP Feb  2020)
The entire transformation zone is visualised (100%)
There is no evidence of glandular abnormality (100%)
There is no evidence of invasive disease (100%)
There is no major discrepancy between cytology and histology.
There is no history of post-coital bleeding or intermenstrual bleeding
There is no gland crypt involvement on punch biopsy
There is no history of previous treatments
In low grade lesions only
Local Ablative treatments are not suitable for “see and treat” protocols associated with referral with abnormal cytology.
Only in exceptional circumstances should ablative treatment be considered for women over  years of age.

A biopsy should be taken if a CIN is suspected and the results reviewed in conjunction with the available cytological and colposcopic evidence prior to any ablative treatments. A biopsy result should be no older than 3 months.
Symptomatic referrals requiring ablative techniques
Ablative treatments may be suitable for clinical situations (i.e. treatment  of ectropion/cervicitis) if deemed appropriate provided CIN is excluded by  colposcopy.

12.4.2 LLETZ (Large Loop Excision of Transformation Zone)
The Principles for treatment by performing LLETZ/NETZ/CKCB is to obtain complete removal of the abnormal epithelium in accordance with type of transformation zone.
Type I transformation zone – depth more than 7mms in >95% of cases, although aim for <10mms in individuals of reproductive age
Type II transformation zone –tissue to a depth of 10-15mms in >95% of cases depending on position of SCJ within canal
Type III transformation zone – depth of 15-25mms in >95% depending on position of SCJ
The LLETZ/NETZ specimen should be removed as one specimen (80%) as removal in multiple fragments can increase the difficulties encountered in histopathological assessment.
If microinvasive disease is present, it may be impossible to allocate a sub- stage or define completeness of excision in fragmented excisional specimens.
The dimensions should be assessable and recorded in the histology report (100%)
The completeness of excision at the ectocervical, endocervical and lateral margins should be assessed and recorded (100%)
Depth of excision – size of specimen to be obtained (100%)
≥ 90% of women should have Definitive treatment for high grade CIN within 28 days of receiving the histology of the diagnostic biopsy. Exceptions from this standard should be routinely monitored.
12.4.3 Patient information
Information must be provided to individuals having excisional treatment to the cervix, the information leaflets must contain these details: (National Guidelines NHSCSP Feb 2020)

There is no clear evidence that ablative or excisional treatment measuring less than 10mm in depth is associated with increase in the incidence of preterm labour and preterm pre-labour rupture of membrane
More than 1 excisional treatment is not associated with increased risk of infertility but may increase the risk of mid-trimester miscarriage
Treatment has to be tailored to individual circumstances and may require excisions more than 10mm in depth
Should a pregnancy occur at any time following her treatment she should advise her obstetric team of her previous cervical treatment.
They should avoid using tampons for 4 weeks following treatment
They should not have vaginal intercourse for 4 weeks following treatment
They should avoid swimming for 2 weeks following treatment
They may drive following loop excision or local treatment, unless advised otherwise by the examining colposcopist
They may consume alcohol in moderation after treatment
Other normal activities, including light exercise, may continue
Although there are no known health grounds for avoiding travel following treatment, overseas medical attention for complications arising from the treatment may not be covered by insurance
There may be a temporary change in their menstrual pattern following loop excision
Anaesthesia/analgesia
Treatment should be performed with adequate pain control this should include pre-treatment counselling and this should also be supplemented with written information.
Treatment should be offered under local anaesthesia.
General anaesthesia should be offered when it is deemed inappropriate and or on patient request. Reasons for treating under general anaesthesia should be recorded in the colposcopy record.

Consideration should be given to obtaining 2nd opinion from a fellow colposcopist in order to try and reduce GA rates for clinical reasons and sometimes patient anxiety may reduce in offering a female colposcopist. Patients will be added to the appropriate colposcopist list for assessment.
The proportion of individuals managed as out-patients with local anaesthesia should be at least 85%, with an achievable target of 90%. (KC65 and audit)
Inpatient treatment

Treatment will primarily be offered using local anasthesia; where this is inappropriate, a general anaesthesia can be offered. Reasons for treating under general anaesthesia should be recorded in the colposcopy records.
Reason for a GA are classified as clinician or patient indication

Documentation of inpatient treatment

13.7.1 In order that the colposcopy clinical database is accurately maintained (100%) and communication continues. It is the responsibility of the colposcopist to document the appropriate information in the operation notes:
Type of cervix
AWE

13.7.5 Follow up from an inpatient procedure will be determined by the histological result and colposcopist instruction in the operation note. The patient will be advised by letter of results and future management plans. Majority of patients will be discharged post treatment for GP cytology.
13.7.6 Re- admission following treatment
Good practice would be that colposcopy sites should monitor re – admission rates.
IUCD/IUS

It is not necessary to remove an IUCD/IUS prior to, or during excisional biopsy. Women should however be warned of the risk of accidental removal of the IUCD/IUS during the procedure, or of the potential loss of strings which  may complicate future changing or removal of the IUCD/IUS.

Women will need to be aware if they may have to use alternative methods of contraception. They should also have the ability to schedule their treatment to coincide with the first half of their menstrual cycle if they wish.
Insertion of an IUCD may be considered if there is a significant risk of cervical stenosis or pre-existing cervical stenosis in women undergoing excisional biopsies.
Follow up after colposcopy

Following colposcopy examination the emphasis is to return women to the national call-recall system. Exceptions, determined by clinical situations, do occur and may require colposcopic follow up with or without cytology.
The type and duration of follow for certain women will also depend upon;-
Whether the patient has undergone definitive treatment or not.
The treatment type and histological result.
Clearance at margins of excision.
High grade suspicions with low grade cytology/histology.
Cases discussed at MDT – where it is felt that follow up would be more appropriate.
Treatment of glandular/SMILE lesions
After hysterectomy for abnormal screening (See section 5.18)
Follow up of low volume high grade lesions with satisfactory colposcopy including conservative management of CIN 2 (See
Section 5.15.2)
There will be exceptions for colposcopists not to discharge back for community cytology. These might be the following type of cases and will be guided by individual sites and clinic capacity:
Diagnosis of CGIN,
Over  years – where stenosis is considered highly likely
Those <24.5 years with a diagnosis or treatment of high grade disease, therefore Out Of Programme (OOPs)
MDT requests
Cancer cases
Ladies who had re- admission within 4 weeks of treatment - requiring GA haemostasis +/- stitching.
All women remain at risk following treatment and should have cytology follow up 6 months after treatment.
Histological failures should be <5%.

All Patient's treated by excisional biopsy can be discharged to the community for her Test of Cure cervical screening sample. However: If a site has the capacity to run a specific smear clinic, the patient will remain under the care of the colposcopy service until discharge back to recall.
It is essential that the smear form has the appropriate information recorded on the request form so that the lab can report the follow up correctly (Sunquest/ICE-NI).
After treatment for CGIN, follow up samples must contain endocervical cells – paired samples should be taken and supplied in the same pot.
Doubtful and difficult cases during colposcopy

If there are uncertainties as to what is the appropriate strategy for a particular patient, then these case can be discussed at the colposcopy MDT or Gynae oncology MDT meeting as appropriate. A Proforma needs to be completed and forwarded to the site specific MDT coordinator.

Patients should be informed by letter of this meeting and that there may be a delay of informing her of a final management. Any changes in the final management plan should be discussed with the patient. The GP should also be informed of any changes.
Conservative management of CIN 2

Conservative management is usually offered to young women who have not completed her family. Women who are following a conservative management will remain under the care of colposcopy until treatment or resolution, 6 monthly follow up appointment will be offered from first diagnosis.
Patients being considered for conservative management MUST be discussed at colposcopy MDT.
Cases suitable for conservative management
Adequate colposcopy has excluded CIN 3/invasion
The lesion is low volume - <2 quadrants
MDT has confirmed agreed management plan
Patient agrees to attend for regular follow ups with repeat cervical sampling and possible further cervical biopsies.
The patient understands that resolution may take up to 24 months and may still result in treatment.
Treatment will be offered if the CIN 2 has not resolved within  months
Treatment can be offered at any point if there is an increase of grade in cytology, histology or colposcopic opinion/colposcopy grade. Patient request, increase in lesion size or MDT advice.
Resolving / Improving
This is classified as reduction to previous grading at a 6 month follow up visit
Cytology – negative / BNC / Mild – HPV detected
Cytology HPV not detected
Colposcopy grade -.Satisfactory and normal / HPV +/- Biopsy
Histology - reporting CIN 1 or less

If the above criteria is met the colposcopy and smear can be repeated again at 12 months. She can be discharged back into the community for cytology at twelve months if the lower grade is confirmed again.
Discharge to normal recall can occur if HPV is not detected in 2 samples.
It is essential that all cytology forms have the appropriate information recorded on the request form so that the lab can report the follow up correctly. (Sunquest/ICE-NI).
If there are any doubts regarding patient management, they can again be discussed at the MDT meeting for advice or clarification.

There will always be exceptions, although the service should aim to follow the protocol. Where a colposcopist feels that a case would be better managed outside the suggested protocol, the reasons for doing so should be clearly documented.
Pregnancy

A woman who meets the criteria for colposcopy still needs colposcopy even if she is pregnant. The primary aim of colposcopy for pregnant women is to exclude invasive disease and to defer any biopsy/treatment until the woman has delivered.
Confirmation of pregnancy prior to colposcopy is essential for a management plan. Evaluation of the heavily pregnant woman requires a high degree of skill.
All women will undergo Urine HCG with a referral for a High grade cytology abnormality and prior to LLETZ/Ablation. This result should be recorded in the notes.
Pregnancy can be confirmed in the following ways
Patient reports pregnancy and confirms continuance – direct towards pregnancy booking.
Patient reports pregnancy and plans for termination - direct towards GP services.
pregnancy is suspected (lmp late) confirmed or excluded on urine HCG at appointment.
Should pregnancy be confirmed at the first colposcopy appointment, she can be directed to her GP for either booking or termination.

Abnormal samples in women who are noted to be pregnant do not automatically require termination of the pregnancy. Women should be advised of the care she should expect should the pregnancy continue. Discussions should be documented accordingly (use Form SOU 5040 for this documentation see appendix 7).

Pregnant patients may benefit from discussion at an MDT meeting (Best practice). If MDT is not imminent, the MDT pro-forma and pregnancy paperwork should be completed and should the colposcopist be a CNS she may discuss the case with a consultant colposcopist (Minimum Standard).
Pregnancy continues

18.8.1 Women seen in early pregnancy may require a further assessment. If these ladies require a repeat colposcopy during later pregnancy they should be seen by a consultant colposcopist with obstetric skills.
18.8.2 If colposcopy has been performed during pregnancy, postpartum assessment of women with an abnormal cervical sample or biopsy proven CIN is essential
If low grade is suspected/indicated, (colposcopy or referral cytology) –
repeat cytology 3 three months following delivery is advised.
If CIN 2 or 3 was suspected/indicated, (colposcopy or referral cytology)
repeat colposcopy at the end of the second trimester (20-24/40) and follow up appointment issued for 3 months postnatal.
If the pregnancy has already advanced beyond that point,
Repeat colposcopy 6-12 weeks following delivery according to impression

If invasive disease is suspected clinically or colposcopically, a biopsy adequate to make the diagnosis is essential. Due to increased risk of bleeding - Excisional biopsy will NOT be performed within the outpatient clinic –
Loss of pregnancy
18.9.1 Patients should be encouraged to contact the colposcopy service to advise of early delivery or loss of pregnancy.
18.9.2 Should the patient advise the colposcopist of plans to terminate her pregnancy. Colposcopy during early pregnancy should still be performed.
18.9.3 Reports of miscarriage following a colposcopy during early pregnancy
If low grade CIN 1 or less was suspected (colposcopy evaluation or Cytology) - treat as per non pregnant suspected low grade months - cytology @12 months from referral smear.
If CIN 2 oris suspected, (colposcopy evaluation or Cytology) - repeat colposcopy 2-3 months after the loss/TOP.
Menopause
In the colposcopy clinic the menopausal state is associated with:
A higher prevalence of unsatisfactory colposcopy, cytology and histology.
A greater incidence of malignancy (therefore a lower threshold for investigation).
Cervical assessment in post-menopausal women is rendered more difficult because of low oestrogen levels which cause:

Hysterectomy
Women who have had a hysterectomy due to the persisting CIN are still potentially at risk of developing Vaginal Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VaIN) and invasive vaginal disease. (Refer to appendix 3)
All women undergoing simple hysterectomy should have already had a cervical sample within the routine screening interval.
Any abnormal cervical sample in a woman, who is to have a hysterectomy, is an indication for colposcopy to identify the character and extent of the  abnormal transformation zone (if any).
The usual indications for treatment of CIN by hysterectomy are:
CIN needing treatment in a woman with a benign gynaecological condition that would be best managed by hysterectomy (i.e. menorrhagia due to uterine fibroids)
Where two or more local excisions have been performed, the cervical sample and/or is still suggestive of high grade disease (but not invasion) and the woman's family is complete.
The cervix is not easily accessible.
Persisting abnormal endocervical abnormaility.
When there is concurrent CIN and VaIN and a vaginal hysterectomy would excise the total lesion (in a woman who has completed her family).

Patients with CIN should have any abnormality on the vagina mapped by colposcopy or Lugol's iodine at the time of surgery to ensure that any coexisting VaIN is recognised and excised at the time of the hysterectomy.
Follow up after simple hysterectomy (National Guidelines NHSCSP  Feb 2020):
For individuals on routine recall and with no CIN in their hysterectomy specimen, no further vaginal vault sample is required

Individuals who undergo hysterectomy and have completely excised CIN should have vaginal vault sample at 6 months following their hysterectomy; if they have a negative HPV result they can be discharged

Individuals who undergo hysterectomy and have completely excised CIN, and are HR HPV detected with cytology negative at 6 months, should be referred to colposcopy; if there is no evidence of VaIN at colposcopy the individual can be discharged
For individuals who undergo hysterectomy and have incompletely excised CIN (or uncertain excision), primary HPV screening follow up should be
CIN 1: vault sample at 6, 12 and  months
CIN 2/3: vault samples at 6 and  months followed by 9 annual vault samples
Follow up for incompletely excised CIN continues to  years or until 10 years after surgery (whichever is later)
Gynaecologist discharging a patient who requires further vault samples should ensure that the GP receives clear written guidance for follow up
The clinician in charge (gynaecologist or GP) is responsible for failsafe mechanisms for this small group of individuals
Individuals who undergo subtotal hysterectomy still have their cervix in situ, and so must remain within the cervical screening programme.
Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN)
VAIN may be diagnosed with or without concurrent CIN and will require a different management sometimes out of the NHSCSP. (See appendix 3)
Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)

The management of VIN does not form part of the National Screening programme but may be undertaken by colposcopists with experience in the identification and management of VIN (sometimes in conjunction with specialist Vulval Dermatologists). This is not covered by this policy document.
Screening and management of immunosuppressed women
Women who are HIV positive

All individuals newly diagnosed with HIV should have cervical surveillance performed by, or in conjunction with, the medical team managing the HIV infection. Annual screening should be performed with an initial colposcopy if resources permit. Subsequent colposcopy for any screening abnormality should follow national guidelines. The age range screened will be the same as for HIV negative individuals.
23.1.1 For those ladies who are already known to the GU team, they will be advised to continue having yearly cervical sampling in the community.
Women immunosuppressed due to renal problems

23.2.1 Women with renal failure requiring dialysis and transplant recipients All women aged  to 64 years with renal failure requiring dialysis or any other disease with a high chance of needing organ transplantation must have cervical cytology at or shortly after diagnosis.

23.2.2 Evidence suggests women who have renal failure requiring dialysis or renal transplantation are at an increased risk of CIN and cervical cancer and the incidence of abnormal cervical cytology in the renal transplant population has been quoted as between 8.7% and 70%. (NHSCSP 2016 12.2). Some evidence that cervical cytology is relatively insensitive to changes in immunosuppressed women. Early recourse to colposcopy is therefore advised.

23.2.3 All women within the screening programme who are about to undergo organ transplantation should have had cervical cytology performed within the previous year. Depending on the time spent on the waiting list, this could mean they require at least yearly cervical cytology. Co-existing CIN should be managed according to national guidelines.
23.2.4 Post transplantation taking immunosuppressant medication Women with no history of CIN should have cervical screening in accordance with the national guidelines
Women with multifocal disease – immunosuppressed

23.3.1 These ladies can present a challenge in assessment and management. The benefits of diagnosing the increased risk of CIN should balance with the additional psychological and physical trauma of assessment and treatment.
23.3.2 These patients should be assessed by cytology, HPV testing (within the context of the NHSCSP), colposcopy, vulvoscopy and biopsy where indicated every 6 months.
Women receiving cytotoxic drugs for rheumatologic disorders
23.4.1 There is no indication for increased surveillance for women on cytotoxic chemotherapy, long term biologic agents and those on oestrogen antagonists such as:
Cytotoxic chemotherapy for non-genital cancers
Oestrogen antagonists such as tamoxifen/letrozole
Alemtuzumab
cytotoxic drugs for rheumatological disorders or biologic agents for other disorders
23.4.2 These women can be managed by cytological screening according to national guidelines.

23.4.3 If the woman is late for cervical screening at the time she commences a course of cytotoxic drugs, then a screening test should be performed, the direct referral process will refer to colposcopy for any screening abnormality.
Individuals exposed to diethylstilbestrol (DES)

23.5.1  Daughters of individuals exposed to DES are at increased risk of clear cell cancer of the cervix and vagina but not other forms of cervical cancer. These are rare instances (1 case per year in England and Wales). Whilst routine call and recall is appropriate for a normal satisfactory colposcopy, local follow up arrangements by annual colposcopy should be in place for daughters of DES exposed women with suspected abnormalities.
Concurrent gynaecological problems

Some patients will present in the colposcopy clinic with an abnormal cervical sample and a concurrent gynaecological problem. The colposcopy clinic is not the ideal setting which to undertake general gynaecological assessments.

There are of course exceptions to this rule and clinical judgement should be exercised. If the problem requires minimal investigation and can be dealt with easily then this should be done whilst the patient is in clinic. If more protracted investigation is envisaged, i.e. infertility, vulval problem, pelvic pain, menopause etc. then the appropriate referral should made and an explanation to the patient that as further more specialised investigation will be required, a different clinic visit may be necessary.

There are also circumstances where patients will have been referred to the colposcopy clinic from one of the other clinics as a result of having an abnormal cervical sample. In general, these patients should be managed as a new referral.

One special instance is in those who are awaiting hysterectomy and are found to have an abnormal cervical sample. Colposcopy in this situation may be used to define the limits, if any, of vaginal extension of a lesion.
Secondly, if invasion is suspected this should be confirmed or excluded prior to proceeding with hysterectomy.
Other medical problems

If any other medical problems are identified whilst patients are being assessed in colposcopy, these should be referred back to their general practitioner for appropriate referral or management. In some situations the concurrent medical problem may have a bearing on their gynaecological management or be of such severity as to warrant a more direct approach, i.e. direct referral to an appropriate hospital consultant.
Resuscitation

All staff should be aware of the Cardio-Pulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) policy. Clinic staff should know the location of the resuscitation equipment and how to summon help in an emergency. Any new staff should receive orientation as to the location and procedure. It is mandatory for all members of this Trust to have undertaken basic CPR training and to update annually. Staff should ensure the resuscitation trolley has been checked prior to the colposcopy session starting.
Use of equipment
Only personnel who have had appropriate training should use any of the colposcopy equipment. Staff assisting in the clinic will have undergone competencies in order to support the equipment user.

Yearly maintenance should be carried out on all electrical equipment by the designated Trust service engineer. All faults should be reported immediately. For further advice see ‘Guidance Notes on Electrical Safety in Rooms Used for Colposcopy and the Safe Use of Electro surgery for LLETZ Procedures'.
(Refer to appendix 8)
Use of medication
The role of the nurse Colposcopist will permit her to use specific licensed and unlicensed products in order to perform in her role of diagnosis and treatment of Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia.
The use of these drugs are essential for diagnosis and treatment and the nurse Colposcopist role is permitted to use these (BSCCP, RCOG):
Lignospan / Scandonest 3% for local anaesthetic to a maximum of 4 ampoules (8.8mls)
Acetic acid (5%) – as a diagnostic cervical wash.
Aqueous iodine – as a diagnostic cervical wash for schillers test
Monsels solution – to achieve haemostasis
Silver Nitrate – to achieve haemostasis
Topical oestrogen (short term as previously stated) – to maximise colposcopic assessment in the peri/post-menopausal lady.
Dalacin (clindamycin) – per vagina antibiotic cream
Proflavin – for vaginal packing as required
Meetings
Colposcopy operational meetings (site specific)
Colposcopy Leads on an individual site will invite all involved with colposcopy

(clinical colposcopist and clerical administration) to this meeting on a quarterly basis. All members of the team are invited to attend to look at recent colposcopy performance, adherence to standards, discuss any issues relating to the service. Items for escalation can be fed into the regular Departmental business meeting. Minutes and attendance will be
recorded. The Lead Colposcopist or Deputy should chair the meetings. There will be a standard agenda and minutes will be taken.
Departmental business meetings

There will be quarterly business meetings, these are called by the Cervical Screening Provider Lead attended by Cytology and Colposcopy leadership teams in line with national guidance. There will be a standard agenda and minutes will be taken.
Multi-disciplinary meetings

Combined Monthly Colposcopy MDT meetings are held on each site. Explicit details are documented in a separate Standard Operating Procedure (See SOP OG301). This is a clinical meeting and there will be a standard agenda and clinical decisions will be documented.
Cervical Screening Programme Board Meetings

Cervical Screening Programme Board Meetings are held quarterly where NHSEI ensure that there is regular monitoring of screening performance and will lead negotiations in cases of underperformance. Programme boards provide the opportunity for providers, commissioners screening quality assurance teams and other stake holders to discuss service improvements, new guidance and quality recommendations.
Annual governance meetings

There will be a yearly meeting attended by all 3 sites. KC65 stats and audits will be discussed. These meetings will rotate site to site on a yearly basis. There will be a standard agenda and minutes will be taken.
29.5.1  Urgent Interim meetings can be called with at least 2 weeks' notice.
Competency / training needs / observers

All staff performing colposcopy will have either full accreditation or be undergoing an approved training course (British Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology course, BSCCP) which will ultimately lead to professional accreditation. Copies of accreditation certificates will be kept by the service.
Trainees will be required to supply their Training number and produce their log book as requested. Trainee colposcopists will be supervised by a named consultant who has BSCCP trainer status.

The NHSCSP specification requires a Colposcopist to see 50 new abnormal cytology referrals a year to be compliant with guidance. These will be monitored and reported as a rolling figure at the operational meetings, unless a gross underperformance then on an as and when basis.

Medical students/observers/ trainees in the colposcopy clinic must be booked in as appropriate. No more than one observer to each procedure room at a time. Sessions should be arranged through the colposcopy facilitator. The colposcopist is entitled to decline entry to observers who have not booked to observe or train.
Permission should be sought from the patient prior to colposcopy if any additional persons, non-essential for the purposes of performing colposcopy are present.
Each site must have a named colposcopy trainer and assessor – BSCCP train the trainer accredited.
Monitoring and audit
The lead colposcopist is required to ensure that the defined standards are being met and the necessary data is being collected, this allows audit to be conducted against these standards.

All patient data for the colposcopy episode (referral to discharge) MUST be entered onto the Infoflex data base. Individual colposcopist can audit individual performance / own practice using the CYRES data base. Where there is concern arising about Colposcopy practice, there must be open discussions between colleagues. Yearly audit for colposcopist performances will be submitted to East of England Screening QA Service.
KC65 reports will be submitted at the appropriate times in order to comply with national auditing.

Yearly Audit will be conducted designed around the Annual KC65 and the annual performance data at least one of these elements will be audited in detail. Colposcopy will present this yearly. (Usually at the AGM-- meeting)

data.text: Appendix 4: Management of VaIN (vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia)
Invasive vaginal SCC accounts for 1-2% of all gynaecological cancers, and is thought to reach peak incidence during the th and 8th decade.
Although it is thought that only 5% of VaIN will progress to SCC. Given that our cohort of women are in their rd to 6th decade it is felt that a small, local increase in the incidence
of this condition warrants definitive evidence based guidance for its earlier diagnosis, management, treatment and follow up.

VaIN and CIN share a common aetiology with HPV type  &18 often present in both cervical and vaginal precancerous lesions. It is estimated that 1-3% of patients with CIN have coexistent VAIN, and it is thought to be more common in the immunosuppressed patient.

The management of women with VAIN remains debatable because most studies on VAIN had relatively small numbers of patients for conclusive treatment methods. Results of an audit undertaken locally on  women over a  year period showed a recurrence/progression rate of 11.1% on follow up and an incidence of vaginal cancer of 1.33% (Razvi, 2016). This is in line with or better than data from published studies. The consensus of opinion is that women with VAIN I can be managed conservatively but those with VAIN 2 or 3 should be offered treatment.
Based on current knowledge of the disease process these local guidelines are suggested Women diagnosed can be discussed in the MDT meeting.
Low grade disease –
Colposcopically/histologically indicated – consider E2 if >50yrs
High grade – progression of the disease warranting a more aggressive management can be discussed at MDT
High grade disease –management can be in the form of
Medical intervention – immune response modifiers – Aldara®
Ablative techniques – co2 laser, Electrodiathermy, Cryotherapy
Surgical techniques – C02 laser excision, Loop, knife partial/total vaginectomy
Other – radiotherapy
Choice of treatments should be based on
Site and size of lesion
Patient age and medical history
Expertise by treating physician
Patient choice following discussions on appropriate treatment regimes.
When radical procedures are being discussed it is important that information and counselling is given on the possible long term side effects.

data.text: Appendix 7: Guidelines for management of complications after colposcopy and LLETZ procedures (to be used in conjunction with Site specific
outpatient policy)
Complications after LLETZ procedures are fortunately uncommon. This document sets out guidelines for management of such complications.
The following complications will be considered in this guideline:
Pain
Bleeding
Vaso-vagal syncope
Infections and discharge post treatment
Damage to vagina / inadvertent colpotomy
Management of severe Local anaesthetic Toxicity
Pain

The majority of women are able to tolerate a colposcopy and LLETZ procedure under a local anaesthetic with minimal discomfort. The use of pre-procedure leaflets and active support during the process has been known to help women cope with discomfort and pain during and after these procedures.
If women complain of significant pain, it is prudent to check the treated area to ensure that there is no inadvertent injury to the vagina which would cause pain.
The woman should be allowed to recover/rest if needed and monitored. Analgesia should be offered if clinically indicated. Women should be advised to take oral analgesia as required.
Bleeding

Primary haemorrhage is uncommon and will usually respond to adequate and judicious use of diathermy. If a bleed does not settle after this, consideration should be given to inserting a suture (eg. Figure of 8 suture) to enable haemostasis.

The use of a vaginal pack can be considered as well if the colposcopist feels that this is needed. If a vaginal pack is inserted, Trust LocSSIP policy should be strictly adhered to, including accurate documentation, the use of wristbands and plans for removal of packs.
Site specific Standard Operating Procedures should be used to facilitate recovery and admission to a ward.
Advice from a senior colposcopist or consultant gynaecologist should be sought if needed. If there was significant haemorrhage, consideration should be given to admission and appropriate monitoring.
Vasovagal syncope

This is, fortunately, quite rare and the patient should have the opportunity to recover. The procedure should be ceased and she should be closely monitored with a blood pressure and pulse reading and allowed to lie or sit down until she feels better. When she has
recovered, she should be accompanied home as per normal practice, (Follow site specific SOP).
If a woman feels faint after the procedure she should be afforded recovery as above. Infections and vaginal discharge

A vaginal discharge is expected following after a LLETZ procedure. However, if she has an abnormal discharge and/or malodorous discharge, she should be advised to return to her GP for assessment or to phone the colposcopy clinic for advice.
A high vaginal swab and antibiotic treatment should be offered in this case.

If she presents with symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g. Fever, pelvic pain /  tenderness, abnormal discharge), consideration should be given to admitting her for  further investigations (transvaginal scans, bloods, cultures) as appropriate. The colposcopist responsible for her treatment should be notified in such instances. –

Minor abrasions and cuts to the side wall can be managed expectantly with analgesia and should heal adequately without further treatment. If bleeding is encountered, consideration should be given to using local anaesthetic on this area to facilitate haemostatic measures (diathermy or suturing).

data.text: Appendix 9: Monopolar electrosurgery

Monopolar electrosurgery is the passage of a high frequency current through the patient from the active electrode (often a forceps, hand held spatula or scissors) to the return electrode (commonly known as the patient's plate).
Procedure
Pre-procedure patient checks:
does the patient have and cardiac electronic implantable devices such as pacemakers
does the patient have any piercings in the genital area
does the patient have any joint replacement – hip or knee
does the patient have any metallic plates in the upper thigh where patient plate to be placed
The equipment should be checked prior to commencement of the clinic. Set up for use (ERBE ®)
Coagulation (blue) setting– Cutting (yellow) setting –
The current should be blended as this provides some haemostasis during the excisional procedure.
The single use gel pad should be attached to the patient usually the thigh, unless a contraindication exists. Alternative sites for application include buttocks or abdomen.
The entire gel pad should be in contact with the patient as a diminished contact patch could lead to burns.
The plug for the handheld unit should be inserted into the correct port for monopolar use.
The treatment speculum should be connected to the vacuum extraction device to remove the vapours.
Post procedure checks
The site of the gel pad should be checked to ensure no burns have occurred.
If a burn is noted the patient should be informed and apologies given. An incident form should be completed.
Patient Safety
The return electrode should be sighted as close as possible to the operative site.
The return electrode should not be placed over scarred or damaged tissue.
The site should be free from hair.
The return electrode should not be placed close to the site of a metallic implant.
The return electrode should only be applied after the patient is positioned for surgery in order to maintain direct contact with the patient.
The return electrode must remain dry during surgery.
The patient must not come into contact with earthed metal objects during electrosurgery.
This includes the operating table; table clamps and drip stands.
Genital piercings should be removed prior to procedure.
Management of cardiac implantable electronic devices

Where surgical diathermy/electrocautery is essential and is to be used at a site remote from the implanted device, then there is a low risk of an effect on the device which may lead to inappropriate function.

Patients with implantable devices should not have a see and treat loop biopsy. This should be a planned procedure and the advice of the Cardiac Physiologist sought. Contact Cardiac Physiologist with patient details, procedure date and time, type of procedure and details of the device. They will determine if an outpatient procedure is feasible or not.
